title: The Plum Guide: our verdict on the 'Airbnb for the 1%'
text:
The Plum Guide lets you borrow the most luxurious homes in the world - Arnaiz Yano

Where Airbnb challenges travellers to live as locals do, the Plum Guide implores you to live as the other half does.

Peruse the home-sharing website for its properties in any one of the 12 cities in which it currently operates and the opulence is blinding: in Lisbon light, breezy penthouses; in Los Angeles, vast seven-bed, eight-bath mansions; and in Tel Aviv, industrial apartments with floor-to-ceiling windows. Listings priced at a couple of grand a night are no rarity.

When I first visited the site I misread the headline “stay in one of the top 1% of homes in the world” as “stay in the homes of the 1%” - a reference to the top percentile of the world’s wealthy - but it did not matter because the message is broadly the same.

Founded in London in 2015, the Plum Guide has set out to carefully curate an Airbnb for the rich and richer, putting each potential property through a 150-point test then rejecting 99 out of every 100.

It has since expanded to 11 more cities, including Milan, Berlin and Paris as well as the aforementioned, and has 6,000 homes on its books, though maintains its standards have stayed as rigorous.

The living room of the Bengal Tiger, London Credit: plum guide More

There is no doubting the luxury (or at least expense) of its top-end properties: glancing at London’s dearest options, there were four that cost more than £5,000 a night. But many of the homes can be found on other booking sites, too, from Airbnb to Booking.com.

Where the Plum Guide tries to differentiate itself is in its assessment process, sending a “Home Critic” to every place it offers, and publicising no user reviews. According to the firm’s literature, it refers to its in-house testing method as “the science and art behind the perfect stay” and asks its reviewers to score the home on 150 criteria during a two hour trial, from showerhead pressure and natural light to WiFi strength and ambient noise. It also, like Airbnb, details the draws of the local neighbourhood, and distances to key tourist attractions.

On its listing it then sums up the results, as well as mentioning the cons. In New York, a £2,522 per night duplex on the Upper East Side “is a little dark” and the “bathroom and kitchen could do with an upgrade”. At a £2,374 per night flat in Tel Aviv the downstairs living room doesn’t have any windows, while there was some construction noise on a nearby street. A £1,087 per night two-bed in Rome doesn’t come with many ingredients “despite there being two kitchens”.

One of the Plum Guide's top properties in Paris, 'Rue de Varenne III' Credit: plum guide More
